resources.string: Welcome to the World of Farmers
Learn about food, lifespan, and benefits

string-array.name: animal_descriptions
string-array.item: Cattle are large, domesticated herbivores commonly raised for milk production and beef. They play a significant role in agriculture by providing essential products and services.
Goats are versatile livestock animals known for their adaptability. They provide valuable products such as milk, meat, and fiber, making them a favorite in farming communities.
Chickens are widely domesticated poultry raised for their eggs and meat. They are easy to care for and are an integral part of both small-scale and large-scale farming systems.

string-array.name: animal_foods
string-array.item: Fresh grass, hay, and silage are the primary food sources for cattle, providing essential nutrients for growth and milk production.
Goats primarily feed on grass, leaves, and shrubs. They are known for their ability to forage in difficult environments.
Chickens eat grains such as corn and wheat, as well as small insects, worms, and kitchen scraps for protein intake.

string-array.name: animal_lifespans
string-array.item: Cattle generally have a lifespan of 15-20 years under proper care, though farm-raised cattle often live shorter lives.
Goats have an average lifespan of 10-12 years, depending on their breed, health, and the quality of care provided.
Chickens typically live for 5-7 years, although some backyard chickens can live up to 10 years with excellent care.

string-array.name: animal_benefits
string-array.item: Cattle provide essential products such as milk, beef, leather, and even manure for fertilizer, which supports sustainable farming practices.
Goats are valued for their milk, meat, and hides. Goat milk is especially known for its nutritional benefits and easier digestibility.
Chickens contribute to food production through their eggs and meat. They also help control pests by eating insects in their environment.

string-array.name: animal_care_tips
string-array.item: Ensure cattle have access to clean water, high-quality feed, and a well-ventilated shelter. Regular health checks are important to prevent diseases.
Provide goats with a clean and dry shelter, nutritious food, and space for grazing. Monitor their health regularly to prevent parasites and infections.
Maintain a clean and spacious coop for chickens, provide a balanced diet, and ensure they have protection from predators and harsh weather conditions.
